user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of run_usock:
```c
static void *
run_usock (void *cls)
{
  struct WsData *ws = cls;
  struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh = ws->urh;
  unsigned char buf[2048];
  unsigned char *msg;
  char *text;
  ssize_t got;
  int type;
  int i;

  make_blocking (ws->sock);
  while (1)
  {
    got = recv (ws->sock, (void *) buf, sizeof (buf), 0);
    if (0 >= got)
    {
      break;
    }
    msg = ws_receive_frame (buf, &got, &type);
    if (NULL == msg)
    {
      break;
    }
    if (type == WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME)
    {
      ssize_t sent;
      int buf_size;
      buf_size = snprintf (NULL, 0, "User#%d: %s", (int) ws->sock, msg);
      if (0 < buf_size)
      {
        text = malloc ((size_t) buf_size + 1);
        if (NULL != text)
        {
          if (snprintf (text, (size_t) buf_size + 1,
                        "User#%d: %s", (int) ws->sock, msg) == buf_size)
            sent = ws_send_frame (ws->sock, text, (size_t) buf_size);
          else
            sent = -1;
          free (text);
        }
        else
          sent = -1;
      }
      else
        sent = -1;
      free (msg);
      if (-1 == sent)
      {
        break;
      }
    }
    else
    {
      if (type == WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME)
      {
        free (msg);
        break;
      }
    }
  }
  if (0 != pthread_mutex_lock (&MUTEX))
    abort ();
  for (i = 0; i < MAX_CLIENTS; i++)
  {
    if (CLIENT_SOCKS[i] == ws->sock)
    {
      CLIENT_SOCKS[i] = MHD_INVALID_SOCKET;
      break;
    }
  }
  if (0 != pthread_mutex_unlock (&MUTEX))
    abort ();
  free (ws);
  MHD_upgrade_action (urh, MHD_UPGRADE_ACTION_CLOSE);
  return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
Fragments not listed above were not selected for investigation because they are ordinary control-flow and resource-management operations that are clearly executed and affect program behaviour (or are standard error-handling):

- make_blocking (ws->sock); and the recv(...) call implement the input loop and determine timing/behaviour; they are not obviously removable without changing program behaviour.
- The outer while(1) loop and its breaks are the core loop structure and cannot be removed without changing behaviour.
- The calls to ws_send_frame, ws_receive_frame, free(msg), free(ws), MHD_upgrade_action and the updates to CLIENT_SOCKS in the mutex-protected section are tangible side-effecting operations (I/O, memory management, API actions) and therefore not dead code on inspection.
- The pthread_mutex_lock/unlock and abort() calls are error-handling and synchronization; they are not dead because their removal would change program concurrency/error responses.

The selected fragments were chosen because they contain branches or patterns that are likely redundant, unreachable, or otherwise suspicious with respect to dead-code concerns (e.g. branches that may never be taken, or control paths that omit expected cleanup). Other areas of the function perform visible side effects or are necessary control constructs, so they do not meet the likely definition of dead code and were not included.
